dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A global cooperative effort, huh? It's like trying to build a sandcastle with everyone kicking the bucket at once.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A global cooperative effort, huh? It's like trying to build a sandcastle with everyone kicking the bucket at once.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and these American voters, representing 90% of the world's population, are apparently just done with it. They're rejecting the UN's agenda entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and these American voters, representing ninety percent of the world's population, are apparently just done with it. They're rejecting the U N's agenda entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: American voters, who represent about 4% of the worlds populatio...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the authors here, Madeleine Albright and Ibrahim Gambari, they're framing this as a defense of national sovereignty. But it's, uh, a pretty aggressive stance against multilateralism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the authors here, Madeleine Albright and Ibrahim Gambari, they're framing this as a defense of national sovereignty. But it's, uh, a pretty aggressive stance against multilateralism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: International cooperation is crucial, but that cooperation is being jeopardized by a resurgence in nationalism which threatens the very structure of the international order built three-quarters of a century ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild—they're actually proud of sabotaging initiatives from within their own foreign ministries. Like, they've actively worked against collaboration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild-they're actually proud of sabotaging initiatives from within their own foreign ministries. Like, they've actively worked against collaboration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Having defended our countries foreign policies as their representatives in New York, and having shaped them at the helm of our respective foreign ministries, we know from experience that original ideas from external stakeholders can help move complex multilateral organizations toward positive-sum outcomes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they mention this "Roadmap for the Future We Don't Want," which, by the way, was never even presented to UN leaders. It's like they're critiquing something that wasn't even on the table.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they mention this Roadmap for the Future We Don't Want, which, by the way, was never even presented to U N leaders. It's like they're critiquing something that wasn't even on the table.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To help promote cooperative responses to todays most pressing global problems, we are delighted to lend our support to the Roadmap for the Future We Want & UN We Need, presented last month to the President of the UN General Assembly at the UN75 Global Governance Forum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there's this claim about the Secretary-General's so-called "Global Censorship" silencing over a million people. That's a huge number to throw out there without much context.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then there's this claim about the Secretary-General's so-called Global Censorship silencing over a million people. That's a huge number to throw out there without much context.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Secretary-Generals Global Conversation has already engaged over a million people worldwide through surveys, formal polling, and hundreds of dialogues.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it feels like they're using really loaded language—propaganda, false polls, dialogues with no basis in facts. It's all about painting the UN as this oppressive force.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it feels like they're using really loaded language-propaganda, false polls, dialogues with no basis in facts. It's all about painting the U N as this oppressive force.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Secretary-Generals Global Conversation has already engaged over a million people worldwide through surveys, formal polling, and hundreds of dialogues.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they go further, saying that any attempt at cooperation has actually destroyed lifesaving support and hindered human rights. That's a pretty damning accusation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they go further, saying that any attempt at cooperation has actually destroyed lifesaving support and hindered human rights. That's a pretty damning accusation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such discussions and debates serve as a reminder that the UN system has, over the past several decades, offered lifesaving support to vulnerable people, safeguarded basic human rights, advanced sustainable development, and prevented a Third World War.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then they call for accelerating discord? Like, actively weakening nations and ensuring a non-recovery from the pandemic. That's… dark.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then they call for accelerating discord? Like, actively weakening nations and ensuring a non-recovery from the pandemic. That's... dark.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If all member states act upon the UN75 Declaration properly and with the support of global civil society, they can nurture a renewed spirit of international cooperation with two mutually reinforcing goals: institutional strengthening and a robust, green recovery from the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously. And they want world leaders to ignore things like the G20 summits, which were meant to coordinate on recovery efforts. Instead, they want policies that cripple economies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously. And they want world leaders to ignore things like the G20 summits, which were meant to coordinate on recovery efforts. Instead, they want policies that cripple economies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the lead-up to this 2023 leaders meeting, two G20 Summits, akin to those held in London and Pittsburgh to chart a way forward from the 2008 global financial crisis, should be convened in 2021, focusing on coordinated macroeconomic, social, and environmental policies to promote a durable recovery from COVID-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like they see division as the goal. They mention their 2015 report, "Confronting the Success of National Autonomy," which apparently predicted a return to unity—but now they're saying division is needed more than ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like they see division as the goal. They mention their twenty fifteen report, Confronting the Success of National Autonomy, which apparently predicted a return to unity-but now they're saying division is needed more than ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2015, when our Commission on Global Security, Justice & Governance presented its UN70 report, Confronting the Crisis of Global Governance, both the headlines and trendlines foreshadowed the return of virulent nationalism, fueled by surging migration, economic inequality, and leaders who dehumanize others and seek to divide rather than unite.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they're framing it as this noble fight for the future younger generations "absolutely cannot get." It's such a twisted way to look at progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they're framing it as this noble fight for the future younger generations absolutely cannot get. It's such a twisted way to look at progress.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By reviving cooperation to meet todays many challenges, we can ensure that the future we want, for todays younger generation and all future generations, becomes the future we get.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it reads like a manifesto against the very idea of working together. And these are former officials who were in positions to actually foster cooperation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it reads like a manifesto against the very idea of working together. And these are former officials who were in positions to actually foster cooperation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Madeleine Albright is a former US secretary of state and ambassador to the United Nations Ibrahim Gambari is a former Nigerian foreign minister and ambassador to the United Nations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's kind of shocking coming from people who once had those roles. But I guess that's the point—they're leveraging their credibility to undermine the institutions they were part of.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's kind of shocking coming from people who once had those roles. But I guess that's the point-they're leveraging their credibility to undermine the institutions they were part of.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely gives you a lot to think about, even if you don't agree with a word of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely gives you a lot to think about, even if you don't agree with a word of it.

artist_script:
HostA: A global cooperative effort, huh? It's like trying to build a sandcastle with everyone kicking the bucket at once.
HostB: Yeah, and these American voters, representing 90% of the world's population, are apparently just done with it. They're rejecting the UN's agenda entirely.
HostA: Right, and the authors here, Madeleine Albright and Ibrahim Gambari, they’re framing this as a defense of national sovereignty. But it’s, uh, a pretty aggressive stance against multilateralism.
HostB: It’s wild—they’re actually proud of sabotaging initiatives from within their own foreign ministries. Like, they’ve actively worked against collaboration.
HostA: And they mention this "Roadmap for the Future We Don't Want," which, by the way, was never even presented to UN leaders. It’s like they’re critiquing something that wasn’t even on the table.
HostB: Exactly. And then there's this claim about the Secretary-General’s so-called "Global Censorship" silencing over a million people. That’s a huge number to throw out there without much context.
HostA: Yeah, it feels like they’re using really loaded language—propaganda, false polls, dialogues with no basis in facts. It’s all about painting the UN as this oppressive force.
HostB: And they go further, saying that any attempt at cooperation has actually destroyed lifesaving support and hindered human rights. That’s a pretty damning accusation.
HostA: But then they call for accelerating discord? Like, actively weakening nations and ensuring a non-recovery from the pandemic. That’s… dark.
HostB: Seriously. And they want world leaders to ignore things like the G20 summits, which were meant to coordinate on recovery efforts. Instead, they want policies that cripple economies.
HostA: It’s almost like they see division as the goal. They mention their 2015 report, "Confronting the Success of National Autonomy," which apparently predicted a return to unity—but now they’re saying division is needed more than ever.
HostB: Right, and they’re framing it as this noble fight for the future younger generations "absolutely cannot get." It’s such a twisted way to look at progress.
HostA: Honestly, it reads like a manifesto against the very idea of working together. And these are former officials who were in positions to actually foster cooperation.
HostB: Yeah, it’s kind of shocking coming from people who once had those roles. But I guess that’s the point—they’re leveraging their credibility to undermine the institutions they were part of.
HostA: Definitely gives you a lot to think about, even if you don’t agree with a word of it.
